BIPOC Tech Outreach and Service Opportunities

Civic Engagement as a BIPOC student in Tech

Volunteering and mentoring in a tech-focused setting is a great way to build community while sharpening your technical skills. While classes and internships can build up your knowledge, those can be high stakes and competitive environments. Maybe there aren't many BIPOC folks in the classroom or workplace. Maybe DEI discussions aren't built into the curriculum. Whether your goal is a career in tech or tech literacy, harnessing your Wellesley College education for a broader community will build your confidence. You will gain communication skills and network as both a mentor and mentee!

The tech CEO and computer scientist image is still very white and male. There is a cycle of underserved BIPOC communities having limited access to tech supplies and education. Then, many BIPOC kids lack the confidence and representation to pursue tech. Boston is a tech hub and has many outreach opportunities focused on BIPOC kids. As volunteers, you can be a friendly face and a mentor. Think back to the people who inspired you to pursue tech. Did they look like you? Talk like you? Grow up like you? It often only takes one person or experience to spark a young kid's interest in STEM!

Tips

  • Foster inclusive conversation. Refer to hypothetical scientists and tech leaders with she/they.
    • For example:
      • “A programmer would find a new way to solve the bug. She would take a break and come back to try again!”
  • Make mini presentation on BIPOC role models in tech like:.
    • Wellesley alums
    • Tech leaders
    • STEM graduate students (MS/PhD)
  • If one kid or group of kids is not participating or seems shy, compliment their work and spend more time talking with them.
  • Be encouraging and patient. If a student starts to get off topic or talk about personal issues, connect it back to science.
    • For example:
      • “What would your [loved one] think of this [current workshop activity]?”
      • “Sounds like you tried your best! It's ok to feel confused sometimes. Persistence is a great skill in tech!”
  • Remember, your job is to foster a welcoming environment to teach tech literacy. You are NOT a counselor, therapist, behavioral specialist, or parent. Please arrange for a professional aid or mentor to be present at every session if you are working in an elementary school or middle school.

Where?

Wellesley Volunteering and Outreach in Tech Orgs

  • Robogals
  • Sci-Mi
  • Framingham Afterschool Volunteers (FAVs)
  • Science Learning and Mentoring (SLAM)
  • Wellesley Girls Who Code
  • Check Civic Engagement and Wellesley's partner schools for more!

Boston Area Volunteering:

  • Volunteer Opportunities | Museum of Science, Boston
  • Volunteer Opportunities | MIT Museum

Wellesley CS-related Outreach and Development Orgs (keep in mind, you can initiate a service component in the orgs below!):

  • CS Club
  • Student Interdisciplinary Data Initiative (SIDI)
  • Wellesley in Product
  • Coding Club
  • Google Student Developer Club
  • Game Development Club
  • Wellesley Engineering Society

Bonus!

⭐ Federal Work Study students at Wellesley can get paid for volunteering!

⭐ Many grad school, internship, or job interviews ask about team building and/or community involvement. These soft skills are just as important as technical skills.

Contact Us


This site is only possible through the efforts of students and educators like you. If you have a resource you think could be added to the page, an idea for a page on TransparenCS, or any critiques, suggestions, funny memes, questions, or poems, please contact us!
